content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about an experiment in which <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is combined with <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, represented by the following balanced equation. <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid, plus 2 H C l, aqueous, reacts to produce C a C l 2, aqueous, plus C O 2, gas, plus H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>CaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> (a) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about an experiment in which <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is combined with <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, represented by the following balanced equation. <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid, plus 2 H C l, aqueous, reacts to produce C a C l 2, aqueous, plus C O 2, gas, plus H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>CaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> (a) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction.

A student performs an investigation to study factors that affect the rate of the reaction. In each trial the student combines <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> of <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> at <math alttext="21.2 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> with <math alttext="1.00 gram" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> and measures the time required for the reaction to go to completion. The data are given in the following table. Trial Concentration of <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"> <mi>HCl</mi> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> </math><math alttext="in moles per liter" overflow="scroll"> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </math> Particle Size of <math alttext=" C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> Time of Reaction <math alttext="(in seconds)" overflow="scroll"> <mfenced> <mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi> </mfenced> </math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> <math alttext="1.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn></math> Fine powder <math alttext="67" overflow="scroll"><mo> </mo><mn>67</mn></math> <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> <math alttext="1.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn></math> Small chunks <math alttext="112" overflow="scroll"><mn>112</mn></math> <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> <math alttext="1.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn></math> Large chunk <math alttext="342" overflow="scroll"><mn>342</mn></math> <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> <math alttext="3.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.00</mn></math> Fine powder <math alttext="22" overflow="scroll"><mo> </mo><mn>22</mn></math> <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> <math alttext="3.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.00</mn></math> Small chunks <math alttext="227" overflow="scroll"><mn>227</mn></math> <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> <math alttext="3.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.00</mn></math> Large chunk <math alttext="114" overflow="scroll"><mn>114</mn></math> (b) The student correctly identifies that trial 5 is inconsistent with the other trials. Explain why the student’s claim is correct using the data in the table.
(c) Based on the reaction conditions and the collisions that occur between particles, explain the reason for the difference in the reaction times for trial 2 and trial 3.

(d) The student claims that the reaction is zero order with respect to <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer using the student’s data.

(e) The <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> was present in excess in all trials of the experiment. Determine the molarity of the <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in the beaker after the reaction is complete in trial 2. Assume that the volume of the mixture remains constant at <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> throughout the trial. (The molar mass of <math alttext="C a C O 3 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is <math alttext="100.09 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.09</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>.)

<math alttext="C a C O 3, solid, plus 2 H C l, aqueous, reacts to produce C a C l 2, aqueous, plus C O 2, gas, plus H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mfenced separators="|"><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded></mfenced></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>HCl</mi><mpadded><mfenced separators="|"><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded></mfenced></mpadded><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>CaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mfenced separators="|"><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded></mfenced></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mfenced separators="|"><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded></mfenced></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mpadded><mfenced separators="|"><mi>l</mi></mfenced></mpadded></math> In order to measure the enthalpy of the reaction shown, the student repeats trial <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> by mixing <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> of <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> with <math alttext="1.00 gram" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn><mo> </mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></math> of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mpadded lspace="+1px"><msub><mi>CaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> using a coffee cup calorimeter. The student records the temperature of the system every <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> seconds. The data are given in the following table. Time <math alttext="(in seconds)" overflow="scroll"> <mfenced> <mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi> </mfenced> </math> Measured Temperature of Solution <math alttext="(in degrees Celsius)" overflow="scroll"> <mfenced> <mrow> <mo>°</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> </math> <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math> <math alttext="21.20" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.20</mn></math> <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> <math alttext="21.51" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.51</mn></math> <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math> <math alttext="21.70" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.70</mn></math> <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> <math alttext="21.85" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.85</mn></math> <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mn>80</mn></math> <math alttext="21.90" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.90</mn></math> <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn></math> <math alttext="21.90" overflow="scroll"><mn>21.90</mn></math> (f) Is the reaction endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer using the information in the table.

(g) Based on the experimental data, the mass of the system is <math alttext="51.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mn>51.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></math>, and the specific heat of the reaction mixture is <math alttext="4.0 joules per gram degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"> <mn>4.0</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi> <mo>/</mo> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi> <mo>·</mo> <mo>°</mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </math>. (i) Calculate the magnitude of heat transfer, <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math>, in joules.

(ii) Calculate the enthalpy of reaction in units of <math alttext="kilojoules per mole reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>. Include the algebraic sign on your answer.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
